meanings.sent1: The rabble gathered in the street, causing chaos.
meanings.sent2: The police had to disperse the rabble before things got out of hand.
meanings.sent3: The rabble at the concert were jumping around and having a great time.
meanings.sent4: The rabble of protesters marched through the city, demanding change.
meanings.sent5: The rabble of children ran through the park, laughing and playing.

meanings.definition: A group of people regarded as disreputable or worthless.
meanings.sent1: The homeless man was part of the rabble that frequented the alley.
meanings.sent2: She avoided the rabble at school who always caused trouble.
meanings.sent3: The rabble of gossipers spread rumors throughout the town.
meanings.sent4: He saw himself as above the rabble of society, looking down on others.
meanings.sent5: The rabble of troublemakers were always up to no good.

meanings.definition: To speak in a rapid, confused, or meaningless way.
meanings.sent1: During the debate, he began to rabble on about irrelevant topics.
meanings.sent2: She tends to rabble when she gets nervous and doesn't know what to say.
meanings.sent3: The comedian decided to rabble for a bit, making the audience laugh.
meanings.sent4: As the politician continued to rabble, the audience started to lose interest.
meanings.sent5: His mind started to rabble as he tried to come up with an excuse.
